DOC.HEAD: Buchwald Says His Movie Idea `Stolen, Raped' by Studio
DOC.TEXT: Art Buchwald amused court spectators with his wry humor but said there was nothing funny about what he called Paramount Pictures' theft of his idea for the film ``Coming to America.'' ``It's very hard for a humorist to be taken seriously in something like this,'' the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist testified Tuesday in his $5 million lawsuit against Paramount. ``I feel this is a very serious matter. I feel my property has been stolen, raped, whatever you want to call it.'' Paramount contends there are no similarities between Buchwald's idea and the hit movie starring Eddie Murphy. The trial was to continue today. Asked by Paramount attorney Robert Draper if the studio's chairman, Martin Davis, is a good friend of Buchwald, the humorist said, ``He used to be.'' Buchwald said Davis did not seem to know about the breach-of-contract suit until the two encountered each other at a party last year. ``The next thing I know a bottle of Dom Perignon arrives at my desk with a copy of a recording called `Sue Me,''' Buchwald recalled. ``I sent him back a note that said, `Anyone who sends a bottle of Dom Perignon is guilty.''' Buchwald said Paramount optioned his story, ``It's a Crude, Crude World'' in 1982, then changed its title to ``King for a Day'' and spent nearly $500,000 trying to develop it as a movie for Murphy. Paramount abruptly dropped its option in 1985 and Buchwald and his co-plaintiff, producer Alain Bernheim, took the idea to Warner Bros., Buchwald told Superior Court Judge Harvey Schneider on Tuesday, his second day of testimony in the non-jury trial. But Buchwald said that Warner Bros. dropped the idea in 1987 when word spread that Paramount was producing a similar story. Draper said he has decided against calling Murphy as a witness in the case because of the ``circus atmosphere'' that accompanied the appearance Monday of late-night talk show host Arsenio Hall. Hall testified that he and Murphy conceived the idea for ``Coming to America,'' in which Hall also starred. Murphy testified likewise in a deposition. Buchwald's 2{-page script idea and ``Coming to America'' were about an African prince who comes to the United States, lives in the ghetto, falls in love and takes a bride back to his country.
